column53: If keeping track of feelings is the task, it appears more related to PEP episodes.
column63: as a goal to be achieved it could be confused with EDR: Enjoyment motivations too. Or perhaps EDR: enjoyment episodes are subsumed by the FM episodes, but prevalent enough to warrant a separate category
column67: to aid with my task, or this could be confused with EDR: distraction or just about any unfocused listening goal / adjacent goal
column69: Heavily overlaps with EDR: distraction. Certain specific goals will show such overlaps between episode types, but if the goal is to capture the core of the episodes this could be confusing
column76:
The core components of self-actualisation seems absent. Music as a aid to fulfilling ones 'true' potential and as a task aid that improves the quality of the task being done.

There may be a missing social aspect of this in group work. (e.g. we work better together, music keeps us on task; music motivates us; etc.)

column59: Seems relevant, and perhaps more negative (i.e., the music runs counter to goals/functions). Not seen so many negative items so far!
column61: Could be a tricky one to answer?

column73: I can see the sense in this, although it may feel a strange item to respond to?
column76:
Perhaps the main consistent pattern in my responses concerns various items alluding to arousal and mood regulation, which could be applicable for EDR episodes, as opposed to FM episodes (this feels more clear with the mood regulation items). 

I am not sure if I saw the 'musical meaning' or 'situational context' descriptive schemes come through so clearly in the items? Could there be something about blocking our external stimulation/distraction to afford focus (i.e., context), or even something about a 'lack of meaning' in the music chosen for focus (so as not to introduce more disruption)? These are only immediate thoughts that come to mind!

column21: To me, this seems more about mood management than FM. I personally view this dimension as being almost more about auditory regulation to achieve a desired cognitive state, rather than to alleviate negative emotions. There feels like there should be something more of a distinction in there.
column23: Similar to before, although I do quite like the idea of enhancement. Exaggerating rather than changing mood feels consistent with the idea of motivation!
column25: I follow the logic of this item, but I wonder whether it could be more clearly related to FM? Perhaps noting that this reduction in anxiety enabled greater focus? For example, "I listened to the music to reduce my anxiety which helped me focus" or something.
column29: This reads more like it should sit with the EDR items to me personally.
column35: As with some other items, I read that this should sit with the EDR rather than FM items.
column41: This feels more social and emotional than FM.
column43: I think this item seems more like a Connection-Bonding item than a Focus and Motivation one.
column45: I read this as being more related to CB still, but I do see greater relevance here.
column51: It might be worth considering a brief extension to this item (e.g., "The music motivated me to complete my task"). In my reading of the scope of this scheme, this may just help retain some more specificity.
column59: This item reads as being negative, which I have reservations around since participants can find these confusing given the positive framing of other items.
column67: Although somewhat relevant, I'd personally say this item could be more closely related to the scheme. I feel this could currently relate to other schemes (e.g., EDR), and so may not be clearly represented FM enough.
column69: As before, I think this could be more specific to the scheme. Music listening to pass time may plausibly be present in other schemes also, and so I'm not sure this reads as being exclusive enough to this dimension.
column73: I think this is perhaps too context-dependent. In my mind, FM could relate to motivation indeed (e.g., exercise in the gym), however, it could also relate to work focus specifically, but not necessarily at the same time. The music selected may be very different in these contexts and not equally represent motivations (e.g., heavy metal when exercising seems more likely to elicit perceptions of motivation, whereas ambient music when working seems less likely to evoke such perceptions so much as focus). I would therefore suggest some consideration here as to whether you think the internal facets of the dimensions should be consistent contextually, as I would expect some variation here (and some noise in this particular item). Hope that makes sense!
column76:
I think that some of these items sometimes read as being from a different scheme (e.g., items referring to the avoidance of negative thoughts). I therefore think there could be some restructuring with some of the items between the schema.

I also think there could be some greater recognition that focus and motivation may not necessarily be consistent between activities. For example, focus is of greater importance during work or study whereas motivation may be of greater importance during exercise. Though related, I wonder if this delineation is important to consider moving forward.

column33: modify the by to in Listening to the music

column57: It seems to have to do with attention modality than with the intention behind the use of music.
column76:
I don't remember seeing items related to achieving "group coordination" for a task.

I also think you could include items about using music to perform a task in time with the music, i.e. with a steady rhythm, even when the person is alone. E.g. jogging, cycling, working out in the gym, etc.

column59: This seems the opposite of Focus-Motivation. It belongs in EDR.
column76: The four types of situational cues (cognitive, affective, motivational, social / transactional) don't all seem to fit well in the Focus-Motivation schema. Many of the items, especially the affective F-M questions, seem to fit more neatly in Enjoyment-Distraction-Relaxation.

column19: Not too sure if excitement necessarily translates into the use of music for motivation and focus - could also be for entertainment, leisure, etc

column31: I think this item has a potential to be more relevant with an added association to a task, e.g. The music made "completing my work" less boring
column37: Why specifically "get ready"? How about other things like "complete my task"?
column57: This item reads fine in itself, but I think it is more related to how absorbed / engaged a person is with the music (possibly under Listening modes & Agency "Diffuse"). As such, if applied to FM, it does not necessarily mean more "caught up in the music" -> more focus on the music -> less focus on the task
column61: It feels a bit strange to me that one feels productive as a result of being motivated by the music. It likely is that one feels productive by accomplishing the task at hand as a result of the music motivating them. If so, consider: "The music made me more motivated and productive"
column63: This item seems to be measuring the intent of the person, instead of how much the person actually used music for Focus or Motivation.
column67: I think the item can be made more relevant by associating it with a task: I needed music in the background "to help me focus on my task" / "to motivate me"
column76: Currently, the items mostly use "focus" and "motivate" - I think there could be a mix with the use of some other synonyms such as "concentrate" too.
